docs.snippet: It's time to crown our August Sentence of the Month. The choice, as always, will be hard. But isn't that what the Internet is all about: exerting ourselves through sustained hard thinking, ignoring all distractions, in order to make extremely diff...
docs.lead_paragraph: It's time to crown our August Sentence of the Month. The choice, as always, will be hard. But isn't that what the Internet is all about: exerting ourselves through sustained hard thinking, ignoring all distractions, in order to make extremely difficult choices? (Have you watched Google's Freddie Mercury tribute yet, by the way? It's amazing. After that, definitely watch the official nonanimated video for "Don't Stop Me Now" to see awkwardly sustained close-ups of Mercury's amazing mouth.) Here are our winners from August:

headline.main: Sentence of the Week, Life-Precepts Edition

docs.abstract: It's time to crown our August Sentence of the Month. The choice, as always, will be hard. But isn't that what the Internet is all about: exerting ourselves through sustained hard thinking, ignoring all distractions, in order to make extremely difficult choices?

docs.snippet: Google's purchase of Zagat got Gadgetwise thinking: what apps and sites do we use to find restaurants? Here's our roundup....

headline.main: Apps and Sites for Restaurant Hunters

docs.abstract: Google's purchase of Zagat got Gadgetwise thinking: what apps and sites do we use to find restaurants? Here's our roundup.

byline.original: By JOSHUA BRUSTEIN and SAM GROBART

docs.snippet: Google's purchase of Zagat got Gadgetwise thinking: what apps and sites do we use to find restaurants? Here's our roundup....
docs.lead_paragraph: The news on Thursday that Google is buying Zagat, the longtime publisher of restaurant reviews, got us thinking over here at Gadgetwise, mostly about the fact that we haven't really used Zagat all that much in the last few years. There are times where it can be useful (if you're going to a city with limited restaurant-review options, Zagat can steer you to a place that will probably be just fine, and possibly great), but what Zagat used to have to itself has become its own industry with plenty of competitors. Here's a look at some of the bigger and better players in the restaurant search world.

headline.main: Apps and Sites for Restaurant Hunters

docs.abstract: Google's purchase of Zagat got Gadgetwise thinking: what apps and sites do we use to find restaurants? Here's our roundup.

byline.original: By JOSHUA BRUSTEIN and SAM GROBART

headline.main: Google Breaks Silence on Energy Use

docs.abstract: Every time someone Googles, a data center somewhere uses electricity.

docs.snippet: Every time someone Googles, a data center somewhere uses electricity....
docs.lead_paragraph: Google has disclosed that it continuously uses enough electricity to power 200,000 homes, James Glanz reports. Still, the company asserts that it makes the world a greener place because it enables people to search the Internet rather than, say, drive to a library and generate emissions.

headline.main: Google Breaks Silence on Energy Use

docs.snippet: Google, continuing to seek a path into the large market in local Web advertising, announced on Thursday that it would acquire Zagat, which publishes customer-generated restaurant review guides. Google will be able to compete directly with online r...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google, continuing to seek a path into the large market in local Web advertising, announced on Thursday that it would acquire Zagat, which publishes customer-generated restaurant review guides. Google will be able to compete directly with online restaurant guides like UrbanSpoon, as well as sites like Yelp and AT&T's YellowPages.com, which offer reviews of businesses and services including restaurants. At present, Zagat offers a subscription-based Web site in addition to its city-based printed guides. In July, it ranked far below the top sites, with 238,000 users. SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline.main: Popular Demand

docs.snippet: Google on Tuesday opened its invitation-only social network, Google+, to anyone who wants to join at google.com/+.     Google+ emphasizes privacy -- like easily sharing with select groups of siblings or colleagues -- and features like  a video cha...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google on Tuesday opened its invitation-only social network, Google+, to anyone who wants to join at google.com/+. Google+ emphasizes privacy -- like easily sharing with select groups of siblings or colleagues -- and features like a video chat service called Hangouts. For Google, it is a way to fend off Facebook, which has been attracting users and advertisers, and gain social data to use to improve other Google services like search.

headline.main: Google Opens Its Exclusive Google+ Social Network to the Public

docs.snippet: You might just escape being Nothnageled in this lively themeless....

headline.main: Friday: Factor Affecting Google Search Results

docs.abstract: You might just escape being Nothnageled in this lively themeless.

docs.snippet: You might just escape being Nothnageled in this lively themeless....
docs.lead_paragraph: FRIDAY'S PUZZLE - When you write about something that is created by different people every day, like, oh, I don't know, crossword puzzles, you can't play favorites. Every puzzle is a piece of art unto itself, and each one deserves to be enjoyed and evaluated (notice I didn't say judged) on its own merit. It's not easy; there are bound to be constructors whose styles I am more in sync with than others. Still, we make every effort to be fair and balanced here, don't we?

headline.main: Friday: Factor Affecting Google Search Results

docs.abstract: You might just escape being Nothnageled in this lively themeless.

docs.snippet: Line2 HD may not be the first app to turn your iPad into a phone, but it is an easy-to-use addition that puts phone calls, texts, voicemail and e-mail on a single screen-and offers a stack of other features as well.     Like Line2's iPhone app the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Line2 HD may not be the first app to turn your iPad into a phone, but it is an easy-to-use addition that puts phone calls, texts, voicemail and e-mail on a single screen-and offers a stack of other features as well. Like Line2's iPhone app the HD version lets you make or receive calls over a 3G or Wi-Fi connection. You get a new phone number (like Google Voice), which can also receive texts and has voicemail.

headline.main: An App to Turn the iPad Into a Message Center

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the most telling moments of Mark Zuckerberg's presentation Thursday morning in San Francisco was a reference to a technology company he said he deeply admired. It wasn't Apple, though his turn on stage seemed to lift several pages from the Steve Jobs playbook. It wasn't Google, from which he has plucked some of his key lieutenants.

docs.snippet: One of the most telling moments of Mark Zuckerberg's presentation Thursday morning in San Francisco was a reference to a technology company he said he deeply admired. It wasn't Apple, though his turn on stage seemed to lift several pages from the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: One of the most telling moments of Mark Zuckerberg's presentation Thursday morning in San Francisco was a reference to a technology company he said he deeply admired. It wasn't Apple, though his turn on stage seemed to lift several pages from the Steve Jobs playbook. It wasn't Google, from which he has plucked some of his key lieutenants. Rather, it was Intel, the world's biggest microprocessor maker. Its co-founder, Gordon E. Moore, is credited with the observation that computer processing power doubles every 18 months. We now know that it doubles even faster. We know too that the logic he so astutely articulated fueled inexorable changes in technology, commerce and life as we know it.

headline.main: At Facebook, Exponential Sharing

docs.snippet: The reignited effort by Republican activists and donors to persuade Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey to run for president may say more about the jittery state of the party's major financial backers than it does about any possibility Mr. Christie ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The reignited effort by Republican activists and donors to persuade Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey to run for president may say more about the jittery state of the party's major financial backers than it does about any possibility Mr. Christie will change his mind and announce a campaign. The Christie-focused lobbying effort took on new life on Friday. It was based this time on poor reviews of Gov. Rick Perry's performance in the Fox News/Google debate on Thursday night, which sent a wave of anxiety through the ranks of activists and donors who were looking to Mr. Perry, of Texas, as an alternative to the other leading candidate, former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts.

headline.main: No Sign Christie Is Shifting for Suitors

docs.snippet: New research from Nielsen shows that marketers may benefit from ad campaigns that stretch beyond TV sets to computers, smartphones and tablets....
docs.lead_paragraph: 12:59 p.m. | Updated The conventional wisdom deems that many consumers may become confused or overwhelmed when ads are aimed at them on different screens in multiple media. However, according to new research from Nielsen, which was commissioned by Google, marketers may benefit from such cross-platform exposure.

headline.main: For Advertising, Study Says More Screens Are Better

docs.snippet: How to save a step when copying Web addresses into a browser's address bar....
docs.lead_paragraph: Live hyperlinks are great for whisking you to the Web in a hurry, but addresses formatted as regular text still require cutting and pasting into the browser to get you to the page. If you use Mozilla Firefox or Google's Chrome browser, you can save a step. After copying the Web address from text, right click on the browser's address bar and choose the "Paste and Go" option to automatically zip over to that page.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Browser Shortcuts

docs.snippet: At Google's Zeitgeist conference for its advertisers and partners, the conversation was wide-ranging but always came back to technology....

headline.main: Notes From Google Zeitgeist

docs.abstract: At Google's Zeitgeist conference for its advertisers and partners, the conversation was wide-ranging but always came back to technology.

docs.snippet: At Google's Zeitgeist conference for its advertisers and partners, the conversation was wide-ranging but always came back to technology....
docs.lead_paragraph: At Zeitgeist, the annual conference that Google hosts for its advertisers and other customers, the conversation ranged far from technology. But Google being Google, it always came back to the ways in which technology is changing the world, from Google's collective brain to whether social media is journalism. Here are a few excerpts from the conference, held Monday and Tuesday in Paradise Valley, Ariz., from my Twitter feed, @clairecm; YouTube and the Web.

headline.main: Notes From Google Zeitgeist

docs.abstract: At Google's Zeitgeist conference for its advertisers and partners, the conversation was wide-ranging but always came back to technology.

docs.snippet: Live hyperlinks are great for whisking you to the Web in a hurry, but addresses formatted as regular text still require cutting and pasting into the browser to get you to the page. If you use Mozilla Firefox or Google's Chrome browser, you can sav...
docs.lead_paragraph: Live hyperlinks are great for whisking you to the Web in a hurry, but addresses formatted as regular text still require cutting and pasting into the browser to get you to the page. If you use Mozilla Firefox or Google's Chrome browser, you can save a step. After copying the Web address from text, right click on the browser's address bar and choose the ''Paste and Go'' option to automatically zip over to that page. The current versions of Firefox and Chrome also support entering keywords in the address bar as a shortcut to a Web search. If you have copied a word or phrase to the computer's clipboard, right click on the browser's address bar and choose the ''Paste and Search'' option to start the search engine.

headline.main: Tip Of The Week
